posts.post_content:
This is [Guardian Beast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guardian Beast) version 2.0. This was printed in Mirage, at a time when Wizards was \*terrified\* of hypothetical shroud abuse. They were worried that A gives shroud to B + B gives shroud to A would result in an unbreakable lock by turn 4 or 5, basically. This was in the days before combo decks could reliably produce a third-turn kill, when the [Stasis](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stasis) lock was universally reviled as eeeevil. Black had [Guardian Beast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guardian Beast) and [Sinkhole](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sinkhole). White had [Swords to Plowshares](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swords to Plowshares) and [Balance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Balance). In theory, Spectral Guide could have tilted what was at the time a fairly delicate balance.  
  
It took Wizards quite a while to realize it was perfectly alright for one card to protect another class of cards, that this could be normal (and was more natural for ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol) than for ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) as the core protective color; if Guardian Beast was printed nowadays it would have been ![Green or White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=GW&type=symbol).). Compare to auto... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

It took Wizards quite a while to realize it was perfectly alright for one card to protect another class of cards, that this could be normal (and was more natural for than for as the core protective color; if Guardian Beast was printed nowadays it would have been .). Compare to auto... (see all)

posts.post_content:
[Hanna's Custody](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hanna's Custody), being an enchantment, is generally seen something different.   
[Leonin Abunas](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leonin Abunas), however, is a strictly better creature than that guy when disregarding creature types: It only requires a single white mana, has 2 more toughness, the static ability is unconditional (doesn't wear off when tapped), and you can still target your artifacts as desired.  
*(But you're also right because of the fact that finding creature removal is always easier than finding enchantment removal)*
